data.title: Nancy Reagan, Queens Native and Former First Lady, Dies at 94
data.meta_description: Former first lady Nancy Reagan, who was born in New York and spent the first two years of her life in Flushing, has died.
data.text:
Former First Lady Nancy Reagan died Sunday morning in her Los Angeles home, at the age of 94. The cause was congestive heart failure, and as NY1's Michael Scotto reports, she was a defining figure her husband's political career.

Nancy Reagan helped define the 1980s.

For eight years she was the stylish and influential First Lady who worked behind the scenes to shape the presidency of Ronald Reagan.

Born Anne Frances Robbins in New York City in 1921, she grew up in Chicago.

After graduating from Smith College, she began acting, starring in a number of movies.

But it was her role as the loyal and loving wife of Ronald Reagan that would define her life.

The two met in 1949, when then-Nancy Davis found her name on a list of suspected communist sympathizers.

Fearful of being blacklisted in Hollywood she turned to Ronald Reagan, then the head of the Screen Actors Guild.

A business meeting blossomed into a fabled romance, and in 1952 they married.

Reagan soon put her career on hold to help advance her husband's political ambitions, which would ultimately lead to California's governor's mansion and then the White House.

As First Lady, she was known in private to be fiercely protective of her husband and his image.

"She was his closet adviser and really his protector," said James Baker, White House Chief of Staff to President Reagan.

In public, she pushed forward her own policy agenda, including her "Just Say No" campaign, which urged teenagers to avoid drugs and alcohol.

After a mammogram detected cancer, she urged women to get yearly breast screenings.

At times, her role came under fire. She was criticized for her lavish wardrobe and for consulting an astrologer.

After leaving the White House, she cared for her husband, who in 1994 was diagnosed with Alzheimerâs, until his death in 2004.

In a statement, the President and First Lady said: "Our Former First Lady redefined the role in her time there."

Former First Lady Barbara Bush, whose husband was Ronald Reagan's Vice President said:

"Nancy Reagan was totally devoted to President Reagan, and we take comfort that they will be reunited once more."

Former President George W. Bush has also chimed in: "Mrs. Reagan was fiercely loyal to her beloved husband, and that devotion was matched only by her devotion to our country."

Reagan will be buried alongside her husband at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in California.
